content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I thought it was fun and path-finding algorithms are interesting to me.

I like it; I need to work on my pathfinding algorithms, though, since I wasted my time trying a breadth-first search when that type of pathfinding won't work with a weighted graph :p.  Nice job on the puzzle.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: This a fun challenge!
Hopefully, Dijkstra's algorithm is not required to solve it :)
The challenge is well-expressed, the tests seems sufficient, and solvable in some minutes.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Seems fun to get in CoC. The problem statement suggests that a complicated graph algorithm is needed, but an easy greedy algorithm works and can definitely be solved in less than 5 minutes
Seems like a harder puzzle than usual, but that would be fun to encounter once in a while

Input
* All descriptions: Please change "integers" to "space-separated integers".

* M next lines: Please format "A", "B" and "T" (I mean the unformatted ones) as [[variables]].

Constraints
* Please format all [[variables]].

* First constraint: Please change 100 to 10.

* Second constraint: Please change 500 to 100.

Thanks.

Thanks for the comments.
The contribution has been updated.

Yes, I tried solving with Dijkstra's algorithm and got sick of it very quickly.

I then tried a neat algorithm that someone used in my clash (I lost with 75% in my actual clash), and managed to solve it in about 5 minutes.

The nice algorithm simply uses three nested loops over the n nodes and updates an array of fastest times between any 2 stations to correct it whenever going a->b->c is faster than a->c, then you can simply use that array to read out the time from origin to destination. Much easier to code on the fly than Dijkstra. Still a hard clash though!

Please be reminded to mention that the integers are space-separated in all three descriptions in Input section. ðŸ˜‰

Thanks.
